content.question: This question is a short free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> points, suggested time <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> minutes) Two plates have equal and opposite charges. The top plate is positively charged, and the bottom plate is negatively charged, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. An uncharged conducting slab is then inserted between the plates without touching either plate, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The distance between the top of the slab and the top plate is less than the distance between the bottom of the slab and the bottom plate. In Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, point <math alttext="X sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is just below the surface of the top plate. Points <math alttext="Y sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="Y sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are midway between the plates for figures <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively. Both the width and the length of the plates are much greater than the distance between the plates, so edge effects can be ignored. The rectangle below represents the conducting slab after it has been inserted between the charged plates. (a) Draw <math alttext="positive" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo></math> signs and <math alttext="negative" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo></math> signs on the rectangle to represent the locations of the highest concentrations of positive and negative charges, respectively. Indicate the net charge of the slab next to the rectangle.

frqParts.text: This question is a short free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> points, suggested time <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> minutes) Two plates have equal and opposite charges. The top plate is positively charged, and the bottom plate is negatively charged, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. An uncharged conducting slab is then inserted between the plates without touching either plate, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The distance between the top of the slab and the top plate is less than the distance between the bottom of the slab and the bottom plate. In Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, point <math alttext="X sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is just below the surface of the top plate. Points <math alttext="Y sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="Y sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are midway between the plates for figures <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively. Both the width and the length of the plates are much greater than the distance between the plates, so edge effects can be ignored. The rectangle below represents the conducting slab after it has been inserted between the charged plates. (a) Draw <math alttext="positive" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo></math> signs and <math alttext="negative" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo></math> signs on the rectangle to represent the locations of the highest concentrations of positive and negative charges, respectively. Indicate the net charge of the slab next to the rectangle.

(b) Rank the magnitude of the electric field at points <math alttext="X sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="Y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="Y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Use <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> for the greatest magnitude, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> for the next greatest, and so on. If any two or all three magnitudes are the same, use the same number for their ranking.___ <math alttext="X sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="Y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="Y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>Justify your ranking.

The conducting slab is removed, and the plates are connected to a battery with potential difference <math alttext="delta V" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Î”</mi><mi>V</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The electric potential energy stored by the two plates in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is <math alttext="U sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>. With the battery still connected, the space between the plates is filled with a dielectric material, as shown in Figure <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>. The electric potential energy stored by the two plates and dielectric system shown in Figure <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> is <math alttext="U sub 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math>. (c) Is <math alttext="U sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="U sub 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> ? In a clear, coherent paragraph length response, justify your answer.

topic.text: 10.2: Conservation of Electric Charge and the Process of Charging

skill.text: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.
